Comment: Welcome to /r/ask_politics.  Our goal here is to provide educated, informed, and serious answers to questions about the world of politics.  Our full [rules](https://www.reddit.com/r/Ask_Politics/wiki/rules) can be found here, but are summarized below.  * Address the question (and its replies) in a professional manner * Avoid personal attacks and partisan "point scoring" * Avoid the use of partisan slang and [fallacies](https://www.wikiwand.com/en/List_of_fallacies) * Provide sources if possible at the time of commenting.  **If asked, you must provide sources.** * Help avoid the echo chamber - downvote bad/poorly sourced responses, not responses you disagree with.  **Do not downvote just because you disagree with the response**. * Report any comments that do not meet our standards and rules.  Further, all submissions are subject to manual review.  If you have any questions, please contact the mods at any time.   *I am a bot, and this action was performed automatically. Please [contact the moderators of this subreddit](/message/compose/?to=/r/Ask_Politics) if you have any questions or concerns.*
Author: AutoModerator

Comment: [Amy Coney Barrett was confirmed in 30 days.](https://cnn.com/2020/09/19/politics/supreme-court-justice-confirmations-timeline)  All the other sitting justices took between 66 days (Gorsuch) and 106 days (Thomas). Roberts took a total of 72 days, but only 23 after his name was submitted for chief justice.  [The shortest ever confirmation process was zero days, twice](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2022/02/07/up-until-the-postwar-era-u-s-supreme-court-confirmations-usually-were-routine-business/). Edward Douglass White was confirmed for associate justice by voice vote the same day his nomination was submitted, and then again for chief justice by voice vote on the same day his nomination was submitted.   Brandeis was the longest successful confirmation process at 125 days.  CNN and Pew are counting days differently, CNN from when the president announced the nomination and Pew from when it was officially submitted.
Author: NYSenseOfHumor

Comment: > Edward Douglass White  It would be more helpful to at least [cite the wiki](https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Edward_Douglass_White#United_States_Supreme_Court) for him rather than an article that just mentions him.
Author: AuditorTux
